A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Does the concept of a/an Integral Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a System of Generators of an Ideal is defined within the context of a ring $R$. This definition requires that $R$ be a ring and that $\frak{a}$ be an ideal of $R$. The elements of the system of generators are elements of the ideal, and the ideal itself is expressed as the sum of the ideals generated by each generator. This definition is applicable to any ring, whether it is an integral domain or not.

The concept of an Integral Domain, on the other hand, is a specific type of ring. It is a commutative ring with no zero divisors and is nonzero. This definition imposes additional conditions on the structure of the ring but does not directly influence the definition of a system of generators of an ideal.

Therefore, the definition of a system of generators of an ideal does not inherently require the ring $R$ to be an integral domain. The concept of a system of generators can be applied to any ring, including but not limited to integral domains. Thus, the concept of an integral domain is not necessary for the concept of a system of generators of an ideal to make sense.
